Step-by-step method details
Fixation of Sulfolobus cells
Timing: 2 days
Cultivate and fix Sulfolobus cells to preserve DNA-DNA contacts in vivo.
Day 1
Timing: 10 min
Inoculate the pre-culture of cells in 50 mL of an appropriate medium.
Cultivate the cells at 78°C with agitation (110 rpm) for 16 h until the culture reaches a growth phase of your interest (mid-log phase, stationary phase, etc.). The doubling time during exponential growth will be ∼3 h for the S. acidocaldarius strain DSM639 and ∼4.5 h for the S. islandicus strain E233S, but these times could be variable if mutant strains are grown or different growth media employed..
Critical: The culture is hot and needs to be handled with care.
Day 2
Timing: 2 h
Fix cells as follows. It is important to take a cell culture and mix it with formaldehyde as quickly as possible. Also, make sure to incubate the mixture at 25°C. Variation in the temperature during fixation could lead to variable fixation efficiency (see troubleshooting problems 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting] for more detail).
Take 20 mL of the culture while keeping the flask in the water bath. Quickly mix it with 80 mL of ambient Fixation Buffer (approximately 20°C). Use Fixation Buffer containing 2.5% formaldehyde for S. acidocaldarius (the final concentration is 2% after the mixture) and 5% for S. islandicus (the final concentration is 4% after the mixture).
Incubate the mixture for 30 min at 25°C with agitation (110 rpm).
Add 5.6 mL of 2.5 M glycine to quench the crosslink reaction. When fixation is carried out with 4% of formaldehyde, add 11.2 mL of 2.5 M glycine instead.
Incubate the mixture for 10 min at 21°C without agitation.
Wash the fixed cells as follows.

Dispense the mixture into two 50-mL tubes and centrifuge them at 3,120 × g for 30 min, 4°C.
Carefully remove the supernatant but leave ∼2 mL of it in each tube to avoid loss of cells.
Resuspend the cells in the left supernatant and dispense the suspension into as many 1.5-mL tubes as you need.
Spin down for 2 min at 21,000 × g, 4°C.
Remove the supernatant and resuspend the pellets together in a total of 1 mL ice-cold 1× PBS.
Spin down for 2 min at 21,000 × g, 4°C and remove the supernatant.
Resuspend the pellet in 1 mL of ice-cold 1× PBS.
Repeat the sub-step f.
Store the pellet at −80°C.
Note: The fixed pellet can be kept at least for a month.
DNA digestion followed by proximity ligation
Timing: 11 h or 1 day
This section describes how to digest crosslinked cellular DNA with HindIII. Generated 5’-overhangs are filled in using a biotin-conjugated nucleotide and then treated with ligase to join DNA fragments crosslinked to each other. Ligation junctions are purified with streptavidin at a later step.
Resuspend a cell pellet in 320 μL of 1× PBS/1 mM EDTA (for S. acidocaldarius) or 1 × NEBuffer 2 (for S. islandicus).
Mix 20 μL of the suspension with 780 μL of 1× PBS to measure OD600.
Dilute the remainder of the cell suspension to an OD600 of 4. For the dilution, use the same buffer as used in step 6. Use 400 μL of the diluted cell suspension for subsequent steps.
If you are using S. acidocaldarius, treat cells with proteinase K as follows to partially disrupt the cell wall. Skip this step when using S. islandicus.

Dilute proteinase K solution to 2 mg/mL in 1× PBS/1 mM EDTA. Add 4.8 μL of the diluted proteinase K solution and incubate the sample for 20 min at 37°C with agitation (600 rpm).
Immediately spin down for 5 min at 21,000 × g, 4°C. Remove the supernatant.
For wash, resuspend the pellet with 1 mL of ice-cold 1× PBS/1 mM EDTA and spin down for 5 min at 21,000 × g, 4°C. Remove the supernatant.
Repeat sub-step c three times for a total of 4 washing steps.
Resuspend the cells with 1 mL of ice-cold 1 × NEBuffer 2.
Spin down for 5 min at 21,000 × g, 4°C to remove the supernatant.
Resuspend the pellet in 50 μL of 1 × NEBuffer 2.
The total volume of the cell suspension will be variable due to residual supernatant not removed in step 10. For accuracy, transfer 50 μL of the suspension to a new 1.5-mL tube.
To permeabilize the cells and remove non-crosslinked DNA-binding proteins for subsequent digestion, add 5.55 μL of 10% SDS for a final concentration of 1%. Incubate the mixture for 15 min at 65°C with agitation (600 rpm).
Immediately cool down the tube on ice for 90 s.
Note: A precipitate could form if the tube is left on ice too long.

DNA purification 1
Timing: 8 h
This section describes how to purify DNA and confirm successful DNA digestion and ligation. Also described is how to estimate biotin labeling efficiency by PCR amplification of a ligation junction followed by restriction digestion.
Dispense the two Samples L into a total of four 1.5-mL tubes (∼560 μL/tube).
Add 1 volume of phenol:chloroform:isoamyl alcohol to each tube and mix by hand. Spin down for 10 min at 10,000 × g, 21°C.
Transfer aqueous phase in each tube (80 μL for Sample U and Sample D and 510 μL for Sample L) to a new 1.5-mL tube. Be careful not to disturb the interphase.

(For Samples L only) Repeat 28. Take 450 μL of aqueous phase from each tube and combine them for a total of 1,800 μL. Dispense the combined extract into three 1.5-mL tubes.
Add 0.1 volume of 3 M sodium acetate (pH 5.2) to each tube.
For Samples U and D, add 2 μL of 20 mg/mL glycogen to each tube. For Sample L, add 2.7 μL of 20 mg/mL glycogen to each tube. Addition of glycogen improves DNA yield and makes the DNA pellet more visible.
Add 1 volume of isopropanol and leave the samples for 1 h at −20°C.
Spin down for 1 h at 21,000 × g (or the maximum speed), 4°C.
Remove the supernatant and rinse the pellet in 500 μL of 70% ethanol.
Spin down for 5 min at 21,000 × g (or the maximum speed), 4°C.
Remove the supernatant and spin down briefly to remove residual ethanol.
Leave the tubes open for 10 min at 21°C to air-dry the pellets.
For Samples U and D, dissolve the pellet in 20 μL of 1 × NEBuffer 2 containing 0.1 mg/mL RNase A. For Sample L, dissolve the three pellets together in 40 μL of 1 × NEBuffer 2 containing 0.1 mg/mL RNase A.
Incubate the samples for 30 min at 37°C.
Pause Point: You can stop the experiment by storing the samples at −20°C.

Run 5 μL of each sample on a 0.7% agarose gel for quality control. Sample U (undigested control) should run as a tight band above 10 kb in size (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]A). You will also see larger DNA stuck in the well. Sample D (digested, but not ligated) should run as a smear that starts from slightly above 10 kb to ∼0.5 kb. Sample L (digested and then ligated) should generate a band above 10 kb as observed for Sample U. It is acceptable to see a small amount of smear in Sample L. See troubleshooting problems 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting] and 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting] for potential problems and solutions.

Figure 1. Quality check of Hi-C DNA by gel electrophoresis
(A) Hi-C DNA obtained from S. acidocaldarius was run on a 0.7% agarose gel together with control samples. DNA marker: 1 kb DNA Ladder (New England Biolabs N3232S).
(B) Size distribution of a typical Hi-C DNA library from S. acidocalarius.acidocaldarius. The library was constructed using NEBNext Ultra DNA Library Prep Kit for Illumina and analyzed by Agilent 4150 TapeStation System and a D1000 ScreenTape. The peaks for the DNA library and upper and lower markers are indicated.
Pause Point: You can stop the experiment by storing the remainder of Sample L at −20°C.
Estimate labeling efficiency by restriction digestion of a PCR-amplified ligation junction. Ligation of two biotin-labeled ends, generated by complete fill-in of HindIII sites, forms a NheI site. On the other hand, ligation of unlabeled ends regenerates a HindIII site. Thus, labeling efficiency can be estimated as how much of the PCR product is cleavable by NheI. If the DNA labeling was successful, 30%–60% of the product will be cleaved by NheI alone relative to that cleaved by the double digestion.

Perform PCR in a total volume of 60 μL using Hi-C DNA (Sample L) as a template, a PCR enzyme of your choice, and the appropriate primer set for the species you are working on (Sac_QC_F and Sac_QC_R for S. acidocaldarius or Sis_QC_F and Sis_QC_R for S. islandicus). We routinely amplify 0.6 μL of the template DNA using 0.2 mM each of dNTPs, 0.3 μM each of the primers, and 2.5 units of Pfu DNA polymerase. The PCR cycling conditions are as follows.

Run 10 μL on a 2% agarose gel. Labeling efficiency can be estimated as the fraction of the PCR product digested by NheI relative to that digested by NheI and HindIII. Note that even the double digestion will not cleave all the PCR product, likely due to inefficient digestion, mutations at the ligation junction, and so on (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]). If the DNA was labeled efficiently, 30%–60% of the product will be cleaved by NheI alone compared with that cleaved by the double digestion.

DNA purification 2 and DNA shearing
Timing: 4 h
This section includes second DNA purification and DNA shearing in preparation for library construction.
Adjust the volume to 100 μL by adding Buffer EB.
Add 1 volume of phenol:chloroform:isoamyl and mix by vortexing.
Spin down for 10 min at 10,000 × g, 21°C.
Transfer 80 μL of the aqueous phase to a new 1.5-mL tube.
Add back 80 μL of Buffer EB to the tube containing phenol:chloroform:isoamyl. Mix by vortexing and spin down for 10 min at 10,000 × g, 21°C. Combine 80 μL of the aqueous phase with the extract previously taken for a total of 160 μL.
Add 0.1 volume of 3 M sodium acetate (pH 5.2).
Add 2 volume of 100% ethanol. Leave the sample for 1 h at −20°C.
Spin down for 30 min at 21,000 × g, 4°C.
Remove the supernatant and rinse the pellet in 500 μL of 70% ethanol.
Spin down for 5 min at 21,000 × g, 4°C.
Remove the supernatant and spin down briefly to remove residual ethanol.
Leave the tubes open for 10 min at 21°C to air-dry the pellets.
Dissolve the pellet in 90 μL of Buffer EB.
Pause Point: You can stop the experiment by storing the DNA at −20°C.
Transfer the solution to a 0.6-mL tube and chill it on ice for 10 min.

Shear the DNA into fragments of 200–300 bp on average using Bioruptor and the following parameters. Power: Low, ON time: 30 s, OFF time: 30 s, Cycles: 60.

Perform paired-end sequencing using an Illumina sequencing platform. We routinely use NextSeq for sequencing of Hi-C libraries. We typically aim to obtain more than 40 million of total reads per library. Although the genomes of S. acidocaldarius and S. islandicus are AT-rich (63% and 65% respectively), we get good quality reads with a small amount of PhiX spike-in (0.5%).
